conversation.content: [hesitantly] Sé que esperabas que trajera un cheque esta noche, pero necesito decirte algo sobre la donación de mi padre. [pause] Ha decidido redirigir los fondos al nuevo estadio de su universidad.
[shocked] ¿El estadio? [quietly] Tenemos 43 familias que no tendrán calefacción el mes que viene sin ese dinero, and he's building luxury boxes for college football?

[bitter] Eso es exactamente lo que hace—hace sus grandes promesas cuando hay cámaras, y luego encuentra razones por las que no funcionará. [sighs] Intenté discutir con él, pero no puedes luchar contra alguien que genuinamente cree que los pobres se merecen sus circunstancias.

[firmly] Tu padre estuvo aquí mismo hace seis semanas, miró a esos niños a los ojos, y les prometió que mantendríamos este lugar abierto. [shaky voice] Ahora tengo que averiguar cómo decirles que necesitan encontrar otro sitio donde vivir para enero.

[apologetic] Mira, he traído mi talonario personal—puedo darte 8000, which I know is nothing compared to the hundred thousand he promised, pero [trails off] podría darte unas semanas más para encontrar otros donantes.

[frustrated] 8000 cubre nuestros servicios durante exactamente 11 días. [exhales] Pero te agradezco que hayas venido aquí en persona en vez de simplemente mandar un email como los últimos tres donantes que se echaron atrás.

[very quietly] Este lugar va a cerrar, ¿verdad? Como el centro juvenil el año pasado y el banco de alimentos antes de eso. [pause] Esta ciudad simplemente ve morir estos lugares uno por uno, and nobody really cares enough to stop it.

[passionately] No, no vamos a cerrar, no bajo mi responsabilidad. Mañana por la mañana voy a llamar a cada persona que haya pasado por estas puertas, cada voluntario, cada antiguo donante—alguien [voice breaking] alguien ahí fuera tiene que preocuparse por estas familias.

[sad] ¿De verdad te lo crees? Después de 15 años viendo cómo se seca la financiación, watching people walk past homeless families every day without blinking? [laughs bitterly] La verdad es que la mayoría de la gente prefiere comprarse un coche nuevo antes que mantener un refugio funcionando.

[warmly] ¿Sabes qué? Estás aquí en Nochebuena, escribiendo un cheque personal de tu propia cuenta cuando podrías estar en alguna fiesta elegante. [pause] Eso me dice que todavía hay bondad en la gente, even if we have to dig deep to find it.
[mumbling] Es dinero de culpa.

[gently] Quizá empezó como culpa, pero no tenías que venir aquí y enfrentarte a mí, enfrentarte a la realidad de lo que esto significa. [sighs] Podrías haber transferido el dinero y quedarte cómoda en tu cinismo.

[slowly] ¿Sabes qué es lo peor? Mi padre dormirá perfectamente esta noche, probablemente ya se ha olvidado completamente de este lugar. [exhales] Mientras tanto yo estaré pensando en esas 43 familias, and how I'm just as complicit in this broken system as he is.

[empathetically] No eres tu padre, y 8000 euros son 8000 más de los que teníamos esta mañana. [firmly] Si de verdad quieres ayudar más allá del dinero, necesito a alguien que entienda cómo piensan estos donantes ricos, someone who can help me navigate their world.

[confused] ¿Quieres que te ayude a recaudar fondos? [laughs] Soy literalmente la peor persona para ese trabajo—no creo en los finales felices, I assume everyone's lying about their intentions, y ya he envenenado a la mitad del grupo de donantes llamándoles la atención en las galas benéficas.

[confidently] Perfecto, sabes exactamente a quién evitar y quién podría realmente cumplir. [chuckles] Además, tu cinismo podría ser exactamente lo que necesito para dejar de caer en promesas vacías de gente como tu padre.

[hesitantly] Aunque te ayudara, que no digo que lo vaya a hacer, ambas conocemos las estadísticas sobre lugares como este. [quietly] El 70 por ciento cierra en dos años una vez que desaparece la financiación principal, and the families just end up scattered to worse situations.

[passionately] Entonces seamos parte del 30 por ciento que no cierra. [pause] Mira, llevo cinco años dirigiendo este lugar con esperanza y determinación obstinada, but maybe it's time to add a dose of realistic pessimism to the strategy.

[exhausted] Vale, miraré tu lista de donantes, pero no esperes milagros. [sighs] La gente con dinero de verdad en esta ciudad lo consiguió pisoteando exactamente el tipo de familias que intentas ayudar, and they're not suddenly going to grow consciences.

[warmly] No necesito que les crezca una conciencia, solo necesito que firmen cheques. [smiling speaking] Y tener a alguien como tú que ve a través de sus fachadas podría ser exactamente la ventaja que necesitamos para sobrevivir a esto.

original_conversation.content: [hesitantly] I know you were expecting me to bring a check tonight, but I need to tell you something about my father's donation. [pause] He's decided to redirect the funds to his alma mater's new stadium instead.
[shocked] The stadium? [quietly] We have forty-three families who won't have heat next month without that money, and he's building luxury boxes for college football?

[bitter] That's exactly what he does—makes grand promises when the cameras are rolling, then finds reasons why it won't work out. [sighs] I tried arguing with him, but you can't fight someone who genuinely believes poor people deserve their circumstances.

[firmly] Your father stood right here six weeks ago, looked those kids in the eye, and promised them we'd keep this place open. [shaky voice] Now I have to figure out how to tell them they need to find somewhere else to live by January.

[apologetic] Look, I brought my personal checkbook—I can give you eight thousand, which I know is nothing compared to the hundred thousand he promised, but [trails off] it might buy you a few more weeks to find other donors.

[frustrated] Eight thousand covers our utilities for exactly eleven days. [exhales] But I appreciate you coming here yourself instead of just sending an email like the last three donors who backed out.

[very quietly] This place is going to close, isn't it? Just like the youth center last year and the food bank before that. [pause] This city just watches these places die one by one and nobody really cares enough to stop it.

[passionately] No, we're not closing, not on my watch. Tomorrow morning I'm calling every single person who's ever walked through these doors, every volunteer, every past donor—someone [voice breaking] someone out there has to care about these families.

[sad] You really believe that? After fifteen years of watching funding dry up, watching people walk past homeless families every day without blinking? [laughs bitterly] The truth is, most people would rather buy a new car than keep a shelter running.

[warmly] You know what? You're here on Christmas Eve, writing a personal check from your own account when you could be at some fancy party. [pause] That tells me there's still good in people, even if we have to dig deep to find it.
[mumbling] It's guilt money.

[gently] Maybe it started as guilt, but you didn't have to come here and face me, face the reality of what this means. [sighs] You could have just transferred the money and stayed comfortable in your cynicism.

[slowly] You know what the worst part is? My father will sleep perfectly tonight, probably already forgot about this place entirely. [exhales] Meanwhile I'll be thinking about those forty-three families and how I'm just as complicit in this broken system as he is.

[empathetically] You're not your father, and eight thousand dollars is eight thousand more than we had this morning. [firmly] If you really want to help beyond the money, I need someone who understands how these wealthy donors think, someone who can help me navigate their world.

[confused] You want me to help you fundraise? [laughs] I'm literally the worst person for that job—I don't believe in happy endings, I assume everyone's lying about their intentions, and I've already poisoned half the donor pool by calling them out at charity galas.

[confidently] Perfect, you know exactly who to avoid and who might actually follow through. [chuckles] Plus, your cynicism might be exactly what I need to stop falling for empty promises from people like your father.

[hesitantly] Even if I helped, which I'm not saying I will, we both know the statistics on places like this. [quietly] Seventy percent close within two years once major funding disappears, and the families just end up scattered to worse situations.

[passionately] Then we be part of the thirty percent that doesn't close. [pause] Look, I've been running this place for five years on hope and stubborn determination, but maybe it's time to add a dose of realistic pessimism to the strategy.

[exhausted] Fine, I'll look at your donor list, but don't expect miracles. [sighs] The people with real money in this city got it by stepping on exactly the kind of families you're trying to help, and they're not suddenly going to grow consciences.

[warmly] I don't need them to grow consciences, I just need them to write checks. [smiling speaking] And having someone like you who sees through their façades might be exactly the edge we need to survive this.

scenario: A pessimist arrives at a struggling nonprofit shelter on Christmas Eve to deliver news that their wealthy father's promised donation isn't coming through after all.
